title: Supermarkets only selling low-noise fireworks as Sainsbury’s announces full ban
text:

A trio of leading supermarkets are selling low-noise fireworks after Sainsbury's issued an outright ban on the explosives.

Earlier this month the chain announced it would not be selling fireworks in any of its 2,300 stores.

Before Sainsbury's dragged the topic back into the spotlight, Asda and Morrisons had made the decision to put low-noise alternatives on the shelves.

At Asda a TNT rainbow selection can be bought for £10, along with a multi-shot box for £20.

Morrisons will be selling a fountain two-pack and four-pack for £6 and £15 respectively.

(Image: ASDA)

(Image: MORRISONS)

Aldi has also joined in the with a Ready Steady Go box crammed full of 15 different fireworks.

In recent years pressure from some quarters to ban or control the sale of noisy fireworks has been growing.

A petition to the UK Parliament to 'Ban the sale of fireworks to the public' was signed by 300,000 people.

"Fireworks are a nuisance to the public," the creators of the petition argued.

"They scare animals, young children and people with a phobia."

Despite the public support, the Government announced it had no plan to change legislation surrounding the sale of fireworks at the end of a debate on November 21 last year.

(Image: ALDI)

Its decision not to adjust legislation means firework detractors have had to rely on supermarkets to act.

Reacting on Twitter to Sainsbury's decision to ban their sale, one person wrote: "Thank you Sainsbury’s for not selling fireworks this year. All my animals spent three weeks of terror. Not fair."

Another user challenenged other supermarkets to following in its wake.

"Please be like Sainsbury’s and ban fireworks and keep them event only," she wrote.

"I’m done with the sound already."

(Image: Getty Images/EyeEm)

A pet owner described how the sound of fireworks affected their dog.

They said: "It's so upsetting to see our rescue Staffie shaking and crying with fear at the sound of fireworks.

"I hope other outlets follow sainsbury’s stance of not selling them to the public. Should be organised events only."

A consultation run by the Scottish Government earlier this year found that 94% of 16,000 respondents wanted to see tighter controls on the sale of fireworks.

(Image: Getty Images/EyeEm)

The results has led law makes in Holyrood to introduce new sales controls, which will be announced today.

Not everyone is in favour of banning or hampering the sale of fireworks however.

According to the Scottish Government's consultation summary, many people made arguments such as: "We don't have any problems with fireworks in our area. Fireworks are great."

Other suggested: "Some fireworks can be good, for morale, and regulations can keep it safe…".
description: Aldi, Asda and Morrisons have announced they are only selling low noise fireworks ahead of Bonfire Night
